elements.content: Two cuprous iodide pseudopolymorphs, formulated as [(Cu4I4)­(MBI)2]∞ (MBI = 1,1′-methylene-bis­(imidazole)) with an irregular cubane-like Cu4I4 cluster as tetrahedrally coordinated secondary building unit and imidazole derivative as bridging ligand, have been synthesized and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Both of two compounds only exhibited a single broad low-energy cluster-centered (3CC) triplet emission band between room temperature and 77 K. Of particular interest, these two Cu4I4-imidazole pseudopolymorphs still displayed thermochromic luminescence originating from a red shift of such tunable single cluster-centered triplet emission, being different from that observed in the previously reported Cu4I4-pyridine system by balancing temperature-dependent multiple emissions (high-energy and low-energy) derived from their energetically distinct triplet states.
elements.clean_text: Two cuprous iodide pseudopolymorphs, formulated as [(Cu4I4)(MBI)2]∞ (MBI = 1,1'-methylene-bis(imidazole)) with an irregular cubane-like Cu4I4 cluster as tetrahedrally coordinated secondary building unit and imidazole derivative as bridging ligand, have been synthesized and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Both of two compounds only exhibited a single broad low-energy cluster-centered (3CC) triplet emission band between room temperature and 77 K. Of particular interest, these two Cu4I4-imidazole pseudopolymorphs still displayed thermochromic luminescence originating from a red shift of such tunable single cluster-centered triplet emission, being different from that observed in the previously reported Cu4I4-pyridine system by balancing temperature-dependent multiple emissions (high-energy and low-energy) derived from their energetically distinct triplet states.

elements.content: Two cuprous iodide pseudopolymorphs, formulated as [(Cu4I4)­(MBI)2]∞ (MBI = 1,1′-methylene-bis­(imidazole)) with an irregular cubane-like Cu4I4 cluster as tetrahedrally coordinated secondary building unit and imidazole derivative as bridging ligand, exhibited a single broad low-energy cluster-centered (3CC) triplet emission band between room temperature and 77 K, and their thermochromic luminescence behavor originated from a red shift of such tunable single cluster-centered triplet emission.
elements.clean_text: Two cuprous iodide pseudopolymorphs, formulated as [(Cu4I4)(MBI)2]∞ (MBI = 1,1'-methylene-bis(imidazole)) with an irregular cubane-like Cu4I4 cluster as tetrahedrally coordinated secondary building unit and imidazole derivative as bridging ligand, exhibited a single broad low-energy cluster-centered (3CC) triplet emission band between room temperature and 77 K, and their thermochromic luminescence behavor originated from a red shift of such tunable single cluster-centered triplet emission.

elements.content: Complexes based on cuprous iodide are currently at the forefront of coordination chemistry and crystal engineering research because of the quest for active materials in optoelectronics. Such research interests mainly stem from the increasing demand for more affordable complexes in preference to other luminescent metal complexes based on precious (i.e., the platinum group) and rare-earth metals, which are often quite expensive and environmentally problematic. In fact, CuI-based complexes or coordination polymers possess the following advantages, which further stress their research interest and potential or practical applications as luminescent materials: (1) they have a large variety of coordination geometries, arising from many possible combinations of coordination numbers available for Cu­(I) (two, three, and four) and geometries adopted by the iodides (from terminal to μ2- and up to μ8-bridging); (2) they present different luminescent levels, which can be of a ligand centered, charge transfer in the case of polynuclear compounds, or even metal-centered nature; (3) most cuprous iodide complexes are characterized by a remarkably high photoluminescent quantum yield in the solid state; (4) the reagents are cheap and it is relatively easy to obtain the final products.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Complexes based on cuprous iodide are currently at the forefront of coordination chemistry and crystal engineering research because of the quest for active materials in optoelectronics. Such research interests mainly stem from the increasing demand for more affordable complexes in preference to other luminescent metal complexes based on precious (i.e., the platinum group) and rare-earth metals, which are often quite expensive and environmentally problematic. In fact, CuI-based complexes or coordination polymers possess the following advantages, which further stress their research interest and potential or practical applications as luminescent materials: (1) they have a large variety of coordination geometries, arising from many possible combinations of coordination numbers available for Cu(I) (two, three, and four) and geometries adopted by the iodides (from terminal to μ2- and up to μ8-bridging); (2) they present different luminescent levels, which can be of a ligand centered, charge transfer in the case of polynuclear compounds, or even metal-centered nature; (3) most cuprous iodide complexes are characterized by a remarkably high photoluminescent quantum yield in the solid state; (4) the reagents are cheap and it is relatively easy to obtain the final products.

elements.content: Photoluminescence (PL) tunability is always the focus of most concern for CuI-based complexes. They are generally highly luminescent at the room temperature, and the emissions are strikingly sensitive to the temperature. External stimulus (such as temperature, pH, solvent vapor, and mechanical grinding) can tune photophysical properties by balancing stimuli-responsive multiple emissions derived from their energetically distinct triplet states in CuI-based complexes. For example, the typical Cu4I4-pyridine system shows two unique triplet emissions at room temperature and at 77 K, respectively. The low-energy (LE) emission band at around 550–650 nm is dominant at room temperature, attributed to cluster-centered (3CC) triplet emission consisting of a mixture of iodide-to-copper charge transfer (3XMCT) and metal d → s, p transitions. The high-energy (HE) emission band in the blue region (400–450 nm) is dominant at 77 K, assigned to iodide-to-ligand charge transfer (3XLCT) and metal-to-ligand charge transfer (3MLCT) transitions. The PL intensity ratio of LE and HE band at different temperatures could effectively control the emission color of CuI-based complexes. In addition, it is generally accepted that terminal or bridging ligands with variable substituted groups play vital roles in controlling the size and geometry of CuI-based clusters and their assembled structures, which further tune their luminescent properties by altering cuprophilic interaction owing to its sensitivity with respect to distortions within the Cu4I4 cluster.
elements.clean_text: Photoluminescence (PL) tunability is always the focus of most concern for CuI-based complexes. They are generally highly luminescent at the room temperature, and the emissions are strikingly sensitive to the temperature. External stimulus (such as temperature, pH, solvent vapor, and mechanical grinding) can tune photophysical properties by balancing stimuli-responsive multiple emissions derived from their energetically distinct triplet states in CuI-based complexes. For example, the typical Cu4I4-pyridine system shows two unique triplet emissions at room temperature and at 77 K, respectively. The low-energy (LE) emission band at around 550-650 nm is dominant at room temperature, attributed to cluster-centered (3CC) triplet emission consisting of a mixture of iodide-to-copper charge transfer (3XMCT) and metal d → s, p transitions. The high-energy (HE) emission band in the blue region (400-450 nm) is dominant at 77 K, assigned to iodide-to-ligand charge transfer (3XLCT) and metal-to-ligand charge transfer (3MLCT) transitions. The PL intensity ratio of LE and HE band at different temperatures could effectively control the emission color of CuI-based complexes. In addition, it is generally accepted that terminal or bridging ligands with variable substituted groups play vital roles in controlling the size and geometry of CuI-based clusters and their assembled structures, which further tune their luminescent properties by altering cuprophilic interaction owing to its sensitivity with respect to distortions within the Cu4I4 cluster.

elements.content: In most previous studies on cuprous iodide coordination compounds, ligands were focused on pyridine, alkylphosphine, or triethylenediamine. Few investigations have been performed on imidazole and its derivatives as terminal or bridging ligand. Could the CuI-imidazole complexes show similar thermochromism luminescence with CuI-pyridine system? In fact, although the thermal stimuli-responsive behavior of CuI clusters is fairly studied through various examples, their emission shifts, colors, and shift directions are still unpredictable. In this paper, we aimed to synthesize Cu4I4 cluster-based structures with an imidazole derivative as terminal and bridging ligands to probe their thermochromic luminescence. The current work for the first time reveals that the Cu4I4-imidazole system only displays a single broad 3CC excited state emission band, which still generates remarkable thermochromic luminescence realized through a dramatic red shift of the single broad cluster-centered (3CC) triplet emission.
elements.clean_text: In most previous studies on cuprous iodide coordination compounds, ligands were focused on pyridine, alkylphosphine, or triethylenediamine. Few investigations have been performed on imidazole and its derivatives as terminal or bridging ligand. Could the CuI-imidazole complexes show similar thermochromism luminescence with CuI-pyridine system? In fact, although the thermal stimuli-responsive behavior of CuI clusters is fairly studied through various examples, their emission shifts, colors, and shift directions are still unpredictable. In this paper, we aimed to synthesize Cu4I4 cluster-based structures with an imidazole derivative as terminal and bridging ligands to probe their thermochromic luminescence. The current work for the first time reveals that the Cu4I4-imidazole system only displays a single broad 3CC excited state emission band, which still generates remarkable thermochromic luminescence realized through a dramatic red shift of the single broad cluster-centered (3CC) triplet emission.

elements.content: Copper­(I) iodide (CuI, AR, 99.5%), potassium iodide (KI, AR, 99%), 1-methylimidazole (C4N2H6, AR 99.5%), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, AR, 95%), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, AR, 99%), acetonitrile (CH3CN, AR, 99%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial, Inc. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements on the purity of samples were carried out with a Bruker D2 phaser diffractometer using Cu–Kα (λ = 1.54056 Å) radiation operated at 30 kV and 10 mA (Figure S1). The PL spectra were collected on a HORIBA scientific Fluorolog-3 steady state and time-resolved fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp. Single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) data were performed on Agilent diffractometers at room temperature (295 K) with graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97, and the refinements against all reflections of the compounds were performed using SHELXL-97.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Copper(I) iodide (CuI, AR, 99.5%), potassium iodide (KI, AR, 99%), 1-methylimidazole (C4N2H6, AR 99.5%), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, AR, 95%), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, AR, 99%), acetonitrile (CH3CN, AR, 99%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial, Inc. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements on the purity of samples were carried out with a Bruker D2 phaser diffractometer using Cu-Kα (λ = 1.54056 Å) radiation operated at 30 kV and 10 mA (Figure S1). The PL spectra were collected on a HORIBA scientific Fluorolog-3 steady state and time-resolved fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp. Single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) data were performed on Agilent diffractometers at room temperature (295 K) with graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97, and the refinements against all reflections of the compounds were performed using SHELXL-97.

elements.content: NaOH (17.98 g, 0.4495 mol), imidazole (4.750 g, 0.0698 mol), tetraethylammonium bromide (440 mg, 2.095 mmol), H2O (25 g, 1.389 mol), dichloromethane (100 mL) were mixed in a 250 mL round-bottomed flask. The mixture was refluxed for 24 h under 45 °C, and then white needle-like crystals were obtained with the yield of 3.254 g.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ligand 1,1'-Methylene bis(imidazole) (MBI)

NaOH (17.98 g, 0.4495 mol), imidazole (4.750 g, 0.0698 mol), tetraethylammonium bromide (440 mg, 2.095 mmol), H2O (25 g, 1.389 mol), dichloromethane (100 mL) were mixed in a 250 mL round-bottomed flask. The mixture was refluxed for 24 h under 45 °C, and then white needle-like crystals were obtained with the yield of 3.254 g.

elements.content: CuI (0.5929 mmol, 0.1152 g) and MBI (0.1973 mmol, 0.0292 g) were mixed in the presence of acetonitrile (3.0 mL) and DMA (4.0 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min to give precipitate, and then this heterogeneous mixture was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 3 days. The resulting colorless block crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by acetonitrile, and air-dried for the subsequent measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [(Cu4I4)(MBI)2]∞⋅(Guest) (1)

CuI (0.5929 mmol, 0.1152 g) and MBI (0.1973 mmol, 0.0292 g) were mixed in the presence of acetonitrile (3.0 mL) and DMA (4.0 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min to give precipitate, and then this heterogeneous mixture was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 3 days. The resulting colorless block crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by acetonitrile, and air-dried for the subsequent measurements.

elements.content: A solution of CuI (0.016 g, 0.084 mmol) in saturated potassium iodide (KI) solution (2 mL) was mixed with a solution of MBI (0.028 g, 0.188 mmol) in acetonitrile (2 mL) and H2O (1 mL). Then this mixture was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 5 days. The resulting colorless needlelike crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by ethanol, and air-dried.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [(Cu4I4) (MBI)2]∞⋅(C2H3N)⋅8(H2O) (2)

A solution of CuI (0.016 g, 0.084 mmol) in saturated potassium iodide (KI) solution (2 mL) was mixed with a solution of MBI (0.028 g, 0.188 mmol) in acetonitrile (2 mL) and H2O (1 mL). Then this mixture was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 5 days. The resulting colorless needlelike crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by ethanol, and air-dried.

elements.content: CuI (0.209 mmol, 0.040 g) and 1-methylimidazole (MIM, 0.026 mmol, 2.13 mg) were combined together in the presence of acetonitrile (0.6 g) and ethanol (1.6 g). Then the mixture was placed in a 3 mL glass tube and heated to 120 °C for 3 days. The resulting colorless rod-like crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by ethanol, and air-dried.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [(Cu4I4)(MIM)4] (3)

CuI (0.209 mmol, 0.040 g) and 1-methylimidazole (MIM, 0.026 mmol, 2.13 mg) were combined together in the presence of acetonitrile (0.6 g) and ethanol (1.6 g). Then the mixture was placed in a 3 mL glass tube and heated to 120 °C for 3 days. The resulting colorless rod-like crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by ethanol, and air-dried.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in monoclinic system with P21/c space group, and the crystallographically asymmetric unit consists of four independent Cu­(I) ions, four iodide ions, and two MBI ligand moieties (Figure S2 and Table S1). Each Cu­(I) adopts tetrahedral coordination geometry bonded to three iodide ions and one nitrogen atom from MBI ligand. The Cu–I bond lengths are located in the range of 2.677(4) and 2.758(3) Å, and I–Cu–I bond angles are in the range of 109.477(3) and 117.296(3)°. The Cu···Cu distances range from 2.634(6) to 2.750(1) Å, being shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii of Cu­(I) (2.8 Å) and implying a strong metal–metal cuprophilic interaction in the cluster. Compound 1 possesses a two-dimensional layered (4,4)-connected coordination network constructed by imidazole derivative (MBI) as a linear bridging ligand and Cu4I4 cubane cluster as a secondary building unit. Each Cu4I4 unit is bridged by four organic ligands MBI to form a two-dimensional structure (Figure a–c).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in monoclinic system with P21/c space group, and the crystallographically asymmetric unit consists of four independent Cu(I) ions, four iodide ions, and two MBI ligand moieties (Figure S2 and Table S1). Each Cu(I) adopts tetrahedral coordination geometry bonded to three iodide ions and one nitrogen atom from MBI ligand. The Cu-I bond lengths are located in the range of 2.677(4) and 2.758(3) Å, and I-Cu-I bond angles are in the range of 109.477(3) and 117.296(3)°. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances range from 2.634(6) to 2.750(1) Å, being shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii of Cu(I) (2.8 Å) and implying a strong metal-metal cuprophilic interaction in the cluster. Compound 1 possesses a two-dimensional layered (4,4)-connected coordination network constructed by imidazole derivative (MBI) as a linear bridging ligand and Cu4I4 cubane cluster as a secondary building unit. Each Cu4I4 unit is bridged by four organic ligands MBI to form a two-dimensional structure (Figure a-c).

elements.content: (a) Four-coordinated Cu4I4 cubane unit simplified into a tetrahedron in compounds 1 and 2. (b) Tetrahedrally coordination mode of Cu4I4 cluster by linear bridging ligand. (c) Two-dimensional layered structure in compound 1. (d) Three-dimensional single net in compound 2. I, purple ball; Cu, light blue ball; C, gray ball; N, blue ball; and Cu4I4 cluster was represented by green tetrahedron.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Four-coordinated Cu4I4 cubane unit simplified into a tetrahedron in compounds 1 and 2. (b) Tetrahedrally coordination mode of Cu4I4 cluster by linear bridging ligand. (c) Two-dimensional layered structure in compound 1. (d) Three-dimensional single net in compound 2. I, purple ball; Cu, light blue ball; C, gray ball; N, blue ball; and Cu4I4 cluster was represented by green tetrahedron.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the hexagonal system with R3c space group, and the crystallographically asymmetric unit also consists of four independent copper­(I) ions, four iodide ions, and two MBI ligands (Figure S3). Similar to the copper­(I) coordination environment occurring in compound 1, each Cu in compound 2 also tetrahedrally bonds to three iodide ions and one nitrogen donor from MBI ligand. Cu–I bond lengths locate in the range of 2.641(6) and 2.801(4) Å, and I–Cu–I bond angles are in the range of 109.316(2) and 117.337(2)°. The Cu···Cu distances range from 2.646(8) to 2.721(4) Å, being less than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu­(I) (2.8 Å) and implying strong metal–metal cuprophilic interactions. Like compound 1, each Cu4I4 cubic unit in compound 2 is connected to four ligands to form four-connected network. However, because of the different distortion configuration of the flexible MBI ligand, compound 2 adopts a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D network (d and Figure S4). Topological analysis shows that the single network in compound 2 possesses an unprecedented four-connected self-penetrating topological net with a short and long Schläfli symbol of 86 and 87.87.87.87.86.86, respectively, when treating Cu4I4 as 4-connected node and MBI ligand as linear linker (Figure S5). To better understand the structure of compound 2, its network can be parsed in a different way, as shown in . The Cu4I4 cubane unit with four MBI ligands (a) could form a single helix (b,d) and double helix (c,e) along the c-axis. The adjacent single helix and double helix fuse together to form a 3D network with trigonal symmetry (f).
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 crystallizes in the hexagonal system with R3c space group, and the crystallographically asymmetric unit also consists of four independent copper(I) ions, four iodide ions, and two MBI ligands (Figure S3). Similar to the copper(I) coordination environment occurring in compound 1, each Cu in compound 2 also tetrahedrally bonds to three iodide ions and one nitrogen donor from MBI ligand. Cu-I bond lengths locate in the range of 2.641(6) and 2.801(4) Å, and I-Cu-I bond angles are in the range of 109.316(2) and 117.337(2)°. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances range from 2.646(8) to 2.721(4) Å, being less than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu(I) (2.8 Å) and implying strong metal-metal cuprophilic interactions. Like compound 1, each Cu4I4 cubic unit in compound 2 is connected to four ligands to form four-connected network. However, because of the different distortion configuration of the flexible MBI ligand, compound 2 adopts a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D network (d and Figure S4). Topological analysis shows that the single network in compound 2 possesses an unprecedented four-connected self-penetrating topological net with a short and long Schläfli symbol of 86 and 87.87.87.87.86.86, respectively, when treating Cu4I4 as 4-connected node and MBI ligand as linear linker (Figure S5). To better understand the structure of compound 2, its network can be parsed in a different way, as shown in . The Cu4I4 cubane unit with four MBI ligands (a) could form a single helix (b,d) and double helix (c,e) along the c-axis. The adjacent single helix and double helix fuse together to form a 3D network with trigonal symmetry (f).

elements.content: Structure analysis of compound 2. (a) Cu4I4 cluster bonded to four MBI ligands. (b, d) One-dimensional helical structure viewed from the b-axis and c-axis, respectively. (c, e) Double helical structure viewed from the b-axis and c-axis, respectively. (f) Single network in a 2-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional framework. (g) 2-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional framework. I, purple ball; Cu, light blue ball; C, gray ball; N, blue ball; and Cu4I4 cluster was represented by green tetrahedron.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structure analysis of compound 2. (a) Cu4I4 cluster bonded to four MBI ligands. (b, d) One-dimensional helical structure viewed from the b-axis and c-axis, respectively. (c, e) Double helical structure viewed from the b-axis and c-axis, respectively. (f) Single network in a 2-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional framework. (g) 2-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional framework. I, purple ball; Cu, light blue ball; C, gray ball; N, blue ball; and Cu4I4 cluster was represented by green tetrahedron.

elements.content: Although compounds 1 and 2 are pseudopolymorph with the same Cu4I4 cubane unit and bridging ligand, the different distortion configurations of the flexible MBI ligand still results in subtle variation in the Cu–I bond length and I–Cu–I bond angle (Tables S2 and S3). To further probe the effect of imidazole ligand on the configuration of Cu4I4 cluster, we purposely synthesized compound 3, formulated as [(Cu4I4)­(MIM)4]∞, consisting of a discrete Cu4I4 cluster with 1-methyl imidazole (MIM) as the terminal ligand (Figure S6). The Cu–I bond lengths, I–Cu–I bond angles, and Cu···Cu distances are all in the rational range (Table S4), being similar to that observed in compounds 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: Although compounds 1 and 2 are pseudopolymorph with the same Cu4I4 cubane unit and bridging ligand, the different distortion configurations of the flexible MBI ligand still results in subtle variation in the Cu-I bond length and I-Cu-I bond angle (Tables S2 and S3). To further probe the effect of imidazole ligand on the configuration of Cu4I4 cluster, we purposely synthesized compound 3, formulated as [(Cu4I4)(MIM)4]∞, consisting of a discrete Cu4I4 cluster with 1-methyl imidazole (MIM) as the terminal ligand (Figure S6). The Cu-I bond lengths, I-Cu-I bond angles, and Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances are all in the rational range (Table S4), being similar to that observed in compounds 1 and 2.

elements.content: Emission spectra of compounds 1–3 at room temperature, as shown in the , all display a single broad low-energy emission band centered at 600 nm for 1 (λex = 315 nm), 645 nm for 2 (λex = 350 nm), and 636 nm for 3 (λex = 350 nm) in agreement with the observed orange-red light. Obviously, the origin of the emission signatures in 1–3 at 298 K can be attributed to 3CC transitions, as the Cu···Cu distances in them do not exceed 2.80 Å. The Cu···Cu distance is the decisive factor in control of fluorescence properties of CuI-based compounds. In addition, the internal quantum yields of the compounds were determined to be 1.72%, 1.71%, and 5.85% for 1, 2, and 3, respectively (Table S5).
elements.clean_text: Emission spectra of compounds 1-3 at room temperature, as shown in the , all display a single broad low-energy emission band centered at 600 nm for 1 (λex = 315 nm), 645 nm for 2 (λex = 350 nm), and 636 nm for 3 (λex = 350 nm) in agreement with the observed orange-red light. Obviously, the origin of the emission signatures in 1-3 at 298 K can be attributed to 3CC transitions, as the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances in them do not exceed 2.80 Å. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance is the decisive factor in control of fluorescence properties of CuI-based compounds. In addition, the internal quantum yields of the compounds were determined to be 1.72%, 1.71%, and 5.85% for 1, 2, and 3, respectively (Table S5).

elements.content: Photoluminescent excitation and emission spectra of compounds 1, 2, and 3 at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 3  Photoluminescent excitation and emission spectra of compounds 1, 2, and 3 at room temperature.

elements.content: To investigate the thermochromic properties of compounds 1–3, temperature-dependent solid-state excitation and emission spectra from room temperature down to 10 K were recorded, as shown in –. For compound 1, with the temperature decreasing to 150 K, the LE emission intensity increases with the emission peak slightly red-shifted. However, when below 98 K, the LE emission continues red shifting and begins to weaken. At the range of 68 to 10 K, the LE band at around 648 nm is still dominant, being accompanied by a new weak emission band at approximately 510 nm. The new emission band is not in the blue light region, so it cannot be attributed to the imidazole-involved high-energy excited state, such as iodine-to-ligand charge-transfer (XLCT) and metal-to-imidazole charge-transfer (MLCT). This weak green emission is possibly assigned as originating from a ligand-to-copper transition (LMCT). For compound 2, with the temperature decreasing from room temperature to 10 K, the LE emission band is progressively red-shifted from 645 to 685 nm and accompanied by a shoulder at 550 nm. All the same, no obvious HE emission band at around 400–500 nm is observed during the temperature decreasing. This dramatic red shift of about 40 nm makes it easy to detect the color change by the naked eye (). Similar to compound 2, upon lowering the temperature to 10 K, luminescence in compound 3 is also dominated by cluster-centered (3CC) emission. The single broad LE emission band is marginally red-shifted to 668 nm, which is accompanied by widening of the bandwidth.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the thermochromic properties of compounds 1-3, temperature-dependent solid-state excitation and emission spectra from room temperature down to 10 K were recorded, as shown in  -. For compound 1, with the temperature decreasing to 150 K, the LE emission intensity increases with the emission peak slightly red-shifted. However, when below 98 K, the LE emission continues red shifting and begins to weaken. At the range of 68 to 10 K, the LE band at around 648 nm is still dominant, being accompanied by a new weak emission band at approximately 510 nm. The new emission band is not in the blue light region, so it cannot be attributed to the imidazole-involved high-energy excited state, such as iodine-to-ligand charge-transfer (XLCT) and metal-to-imidazole charge-transfer (MLCT). This weak green emission is possibly assigned as originating from a ligand-to-copper transition (LMCT). For compound 2, with the temperature decreasing from room temperature to 10 K, the LE emission band is progressively red-shifted from 645 to 685 nm and accompanied by a shoulder at 550 nm. All the same, no obvious HE emission band at around 400-500 nm is observed during the temperature decreasing. This dramatic red shift of about 40 nm makes it easy to detect the color change by the naked eye (). Similar to compound 2, upon lowering the temperature to 10 K, luminescence in compound 3 is also dominated by cluster-centered (3CC) emission. The single broad LE emission band is marginally red-shifted to 668 nm, which is accompanied by widening of the bandwidth.

elements.content: Above data show that the origin of thermochromic luminescence in 1–3 is originated only from a single broad tunable LE emission, being quite different from typical Cu4I4(pyridine)4 cluster-based compounds where relative intensities of LE (3CC) and HE (XLCT) emissions at different temperatures are responsible for thermochromic luminescence. The absolute predomination of LE emission at room temperature and the absence of HE emission at low temperature in compounds 1–3 possibly are the synergistic effects coming from the Cu4I4 cluster with strong cuprophilic interaction in it and imidazole ligand with unmatchable π* molecular orbital for ligand-involved triplet transition. As displayed in structural data, the relatively flexible bridging ligand MBI and terminal ligand MIM cannot cause the serious distortion of the Cu4I4 cluster. The Cu···Cu distances in compounds 1–3 is in the narrow range and always less than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu­(I) (2.8 Å). Only a strong stimulus, such as pretty low temperature, can cause a subtle change in the Cu···Cu distances, which further results in the large positive Stoke’s shift in its PL spectrum. Weak stimulus, such as mechanical attrition treatment, cannot lead to further alteration in the Cu···Cu distances. Thus, compared with the unground sample, a similar emission color for the ground sample is observed, as shown in –.
elements.clean_text: Above data show that the origin of thermochromic luminescence in 1-3 is originated only from a single broad tunable LE emission, being quite different from typical Cu4I4(pyridine)4 cluster-based compounds where relative intensities of LE (3CC) and HE (XLCT) emissions at different temperatures are responsible for thermochromic luminescence. The absolute predomination of LE emission at room temperature and the absence of HE emission at low temperature in compounds 1-3 possibly are the synergistic effects coming from the Cu4I4 cluster with strong cuprophilic interaction in it and imidazole ligand with unmatchable π* molecular orbital for ligand-involved triplet transition. As displayed in structural data, the relatively flexible bridging ligand MBI and terminal ligand MIM cannot cause the serious distortion of the Cu4I4 cluster. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances in compounds 1-3 is in the narrow range and always less than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu(I) (2.8 Å). Only a strong stimulus, such as pretty low temperature, can cause a subtle change in the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances, which further results in the large positive Stoke's shift in its PL spectrum. Weak stimulus, such as mechanical attrition treatment, cannot lead to further alteration in the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances. Thus, compared with the unground sample, a similar emission color for the ground sample is observed, as shown in -.

elements.content: In summary, two cuprous iodide pseudopolymorphs with 1,1′-methylene-bis­(imidazole) as the bridging ligand were successfully synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Although compounds 1 and 2 have the same Cu4I4 cubane unit and bridging ligand, they exhibited a totally different topological network due to the different distortion configuration of the ligand. Different from compound 1 with a typical 2D (4,4) net, compound 2 displayed an unprecedented 3D 2-fold interpenetrated net with self-penetrating 4-connected topological framework. The average Cu···Cu distances in those compounds are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of copper, so compounds 1 and 2 only exhibited a single broad low-energy cluster-centered (3CC) triplet emission band at room temperature and 77 K. Even so, these two pseudopolymorphs still displayed consistent thermochromic luminescence originating from the single cluster-centered triplet emission, which is red-shifted upon lowering the temperature. The current study indicates that the organic ligand bonded to the Cu4I4 cluster can effectively control the thermochromic behavior. This work prompts us to carry out further investigations on other types of organic ligands for enriching the luminescent thermochromism behavior from CuI-ligand systems.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, two cuprous iodide pseudopolymorphs with 1,1'-methylene-bis(imidazole) as the bridging ligand were successfully synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Although compounds 1 and 2 have the same Cu4I4 cubane unit and bridging ligand, they exhibited a totally different topological network due to the different distortion configuration of the ligand. Different from compound 1 with a typical 2D (4,4) net, compound 2 displayed an unprecedented 3D 2-fold interpenetrated net with self-penetrating 4-connected topological framework. The average Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances in those compounds are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of copper, so compounds 1 and 2 only exhibited a single broad low-energy cluster-centered (3CC) triplet emission band at room temperature and 77 K. Even so, these two pseudopolymorphs still displayed consistent thermochromic luminescence originating from the single cluster-centered triplet emission, which is red-shifted upon lowering the temperature. The current study indicates that the organic ligand bonded to the Cu4I4 cluster can effectively control the thermochromic behavior. This work prompts us to carry out further investigations on other types of organic ligands for enriching the luminescent thermochromism behavior from CuI-ligand systems.

cln_elements.content:
NaOH (17.98 g, 0.4495 mol), imidazole (4.750 g, 0.0698 mol), tetraethylammonium bromide (440 mg, 2.095 mmol), H2O (25 g, 1.389 mol), dichloromethane (100 mL) were mixed in a 250 mL round-bottomed flask. The mixture was refluxed for 24 h under 45 °C, and then white needle-like crystals were obtained with the yield of 3.254 g.

Synthesis of [(Cu<sub>4</sub>I<sub>4</sub>)­(MBI)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>∞</sub>·(Guest) (<bold>1</bold>)

CuI (0.5929 mmol, 0.1152 g) and MBI (0.1973 mmol, 0.0292 g) were mixed in the presence of acetonitrile (3.0 mL) and DMA (4.0 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min to give precipitate, and then this heterogeneous mixture was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 3 days. The resulting colorless block crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by acetonitrile, and air-dried for the subsequent measurements.

Synthesis of [(Cu<sub>4</sub>I<sub>4</sub>) (MBI)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>∞</sub>­·(C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>3</sub>N)·8­(H<sub>2</sub>O) (<bold>2</bold>)

A solution of CuI (0.016 g, 0.084 mmol) in saturated potassium iodide (KI) solution (2 mL) was mixed with a solution of MBI (0.028 g, 0.188 mmol) in acetonitrile (2 mL) and H2O (1 mL). Then this mixture was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 5 days. The resulting colorless needlelike crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by ethanol, and air-dried.

Synthesis of [(Cu<sub>4</sub>I<sub>4</sub>)­(MIM)<sub>4</sub>] (<bold>3</bold>)

CuI (0.209 mmol, 0.040 g) and 1-methylimidazole (MIM, 0.026 mmol, 2.13 mg) were combined together in the presence of acetonitrile (0.6 g) and ethanol (1.6 g). Then the mixture was placed in a 3 mL glass tube and heated to 120 °C for 3 days. The resulting colorless rod-like crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by ethanol, and air-dried.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ligand 1,1'-Methylene bis(imidazole) (MBI)

NaOH (17.98 g, 0.4495 mol), imidazole (4.750 g, 0.0698 mol), tetraethylammonium bromide (440 mg, 2.095 mmol), H2O (25 g, 1.389 mol), dichloromethane (100 mL) were mixed in a 250 mL round-bottomed flask. The mixture was refluxed for 24 h under 45 °C, and then white needle-like crystals were obtained with the yield of 3.254 g.

Synthesis of [(Cu4I4)(MBI)2]∞⋅(Guest) (1)

CuI (0.5929 mmol, 0.1152 g) and MBI (0.1973 mmol, 0.0292 g) were mixed in the presence of acetonitrile (3.0 mL) and DMA (4.0 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min to give precipitate, and then this heterogeneous mixture was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 3 days. The resulting colorless block crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by acetonitrile, and air-dried for the subsequent measurements.

Synthesis of [(Cu4I4) (MBI)2]∞⋅(C2H3N)⋅8(H2O) (2)

A solution of CuI (0.016 g, 0.084 mmol) in saturated potassium iodide (KI) solution (2 mL) was mixed with a solution of MBI (0.028 g, 0.188 mmol) in acetonitrile (2 mL) and H2O (1 mL). Then this mixture was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 5 days. The resulting colorless needlelike crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by ethanol, and air-dried.

Synthesis of [(Cu4I4)(MIM)4] (3)

CuI (0.209 mmol, 0.040 g) and 1-methylimidazole (MIM, 0.026 mmol, 2.13 mg) were combined together in the presence of acetonitrile (0.6 g) and ethanol (1.6 g). Then the mixture was placed in a 3 mL glass tube and heated to 120 °C for 3 days. The resulting colorless rod-like crystals were obtained by filtration, washed by ethanol, and air-dried.

cln_elements.content: Emission spectra of compounds 1–3 at room temperature, as shown in the , all display a single broad low-energy emission band centered at 600 nm for 1 (λex = 315 nm), 645 nm for 2 (λex = 350 nm), and 636 nm for 3 (λex = 350 nm) in agreement with the observed orange-red light. Obviously, the origin of the emission signatures in 1–3 at 298 K can be attributed to 3CC transitions, as the Cu···Cu distances in them do not exceed 2.80 Å. The Cu···Cu distance is the decisive factor in control of fluorescence properties of CuI-based compounds. In addition, the internal quantum yields of the compounds were determined to be 1.72%, 1.71%, and 5.85% for 1, 2, and 3, respectively (Table S5).
cln_elements.clean_text: Emission spectra of compounds 1-3 at room temperature, as shown in the , all display a single broad low-energy emission band centered at 600 nm for 1 (λex = 315 nm), 645 nm for 2 (λex = 350 nm), and 636 nm for 3 (λex = 350 nm) in agreement with the observed orange-red light. Obviously, the origin of the emission signatures in 1-3 at 298 K can be attributed to 3CC transitions, as the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances in them do not exceed 2.80 Å. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance is the decisive factor in control of fluorescence properties of CuI-based compounds. In addition, the internal quantum yields of the compounds were determined to be 1.72%, 1.71%, and 5.85% for 1, 2, and 3, respectively (Table S5).

cln_elements.content: (a) Four-coordinated Cu4I4 cubane unit simplified into a tetrahedron in compounds 1 and 2. (b) Tetrahedrally coordination mode of Cu4I4 cluster by linear bridging ligand. (c) Two-dimensional layered structure in compound 1. (d) Three-dimensional single net in compound 2. I, purple ball; Cu, light blue ball; C, gray ball; N, blue ball; and Cu4I4 cluster was represented by green tetrahedron.

cln_elements.content: Structure analysis of compound 2. (a) Cu4I4 cluster bonded to four MBI ligands. (b, d) One-dimensional helical structure viewed from the b-axis and c-axis, respectively. (c, e) Double helical structure viewed from the b-axis and c-axis, respectively. (f) Single network in a 2-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional framework. (g) 2-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional framework. I, purple ball; Cu, light blue ball; C, gray ball; N, blue ball; and Cu4I4 cluster was represented by green tetrahedron.

(g) 2-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional framework. I, purple ball; Cu, light blue ball; C, gray ball; N, blue ball; and Cu4I4 cluster was represented by green tetrahedron.

metadata.title:
Cuprous Iodide Pseudopolymorphs Based on Imidazole
Ligand and Their Luminescence Thermochromism
